logo: ARGUS RESEARCH Summary : This image is a logo for Argus Research, featuring the company name and a stylized icon. Logo Elements : • The logo consists of a blue rectangular background. • On the left, there is a white circle containing a stylized archway or column with a small globe at the base. • To the right of the icon, the text "ARGUS" appears in large, uppercase serif font, with a registered trademark symbol (®) at the upper right. • Below "ARGUS," the word "RESEARCH" is written in smaller, spaced-out uppercase letters. Dimensions & Placement : • The icon is positioned to the left of the text. • The text is horizontally aligned and centered vertically with the icon. Analysis : • The use of blue and white conveys a professional and trustworthy image, suitable for a research or financial analysis firm. • The globe and column/arch motif suggests global reach and stability. NVIDIA CORP (NAS:NVDA) Report Date: July 09, 2025 Summary : This line chart shows the time series of a variable (likely a stock price or index) from early 2023 to mid-2025, with values ranging from $11 to $152. line chart: Title & Axes : • No explicit title visible. • X-axis: Dates, ranging from Jan 1, 2023 to Jul 1, 2025, with tick marks at approximately half-year intervals. • Y-axis: Dollar values, labeled at $11, $41, $71, $102, $132, and $152. Data Points : • Single series plotted as a continuous blue line. • Data points are not individually marked; the line is smooth and continuous. Design Encodings : • Blue line, no markers, no gridlines, no error bars or confidence intervals. • Linear scale on both axes. Distribution & Trends : • The series starts near $11 in early 2023. • Gradual increase through 2023, with a steeper rise beginning late 2023 into 2024. • Peaks above $130 in mid-2024, followed by volatility with several local peaks and troughs. • After a dip in early 2025, the series rises sharply again, ending at its highest value near $152 by mid-2025. Analysis : • The data shows a strong upward trend from 2023 to mid-2024, followed by a period of volatility and consolidation. • Despite fluctuations, the overall trajectory is positive, with the final value being the highest in the series. • No obvious outliers; the pattern suggests growth with intermittent corrections. Over the past year, NVDA shares are up 18.6%, versus a gain of 10.5% for the broader market. The 52 week trading range is $86.62 to $160.98. The Argus A6 target price is $208 representing a 30% gain from the current level. Nvidia is a leading developer of graphics processing units. Traditionally, GPUs were used to enhance the experience on computing platforms, most notably in gaming applications on PCs.

Summary : This figure presents a pie chart and legend detailing the breakdown of Vicker's Institutional & Insider Holdings, including specific categories, their values, and a note on data sources and usage restrictions. pie chart: # Title & Legend : • Title: "Vicker's Institutional & Insider Holdings". • Legend categories: 13F Non Mutual Funds (blue), 13F Mutual Funds (light blue), Insider (red), Other Mutual Funds (pink), Other (yellow). • 13F Total: 8807.9m. • Outstanding: 24,400m. # Data Points : • 13F Non Mutual Funds: 1735.4m (blue). • 13F Mutual Funds: 7072.5m (light blue). • Insider: 92.7m (red). • Other Mutual Funds: 21.6m (pink). • Other: 15,477.8m (yellow). # Design Encodings : • Pie chart segments are colour-coded: blue (13F Non Mutual Funds), light blue (13F Mutual Funds), red (Insider), pink (Other Mutual Funds), yellow (Other). • Numeric values are labeled with lines pointing to each segment. • The legend uses matching colour swatches for each category. # Additional Notes : • The chart is accompanied by a disclaimer about the proprietary nature of the data, restrictions on copying/distribution, and a copyright notice from Morningstar, Inc. (2017). # Analysis : • The "Other" category (yellow) represents the largest portion of holdings at 15,477.8m, followed by 13F Mutual Funds (7,072.5m). • Insider and Other Mutual Funds holdings are minimal compared to the other categories. • The total of 13F holdings (Non Mutual + Mutual Funds) is 8,807.9m, which is a significant but not majority share of the total outstanding (24,400m). • The pie chart visually emphasizes the dominance of the "Other" and "13F Mutual Funds" categories in Vicker's holdings. © 2025 Argus Research Company ARGUS A6 Report logo: ARGUS RESEARCH Scene Overview : • The image is a logo for "ARGUS RESEARCH" on a blue background. • The left side features a white circular emblem containing a stylized archway or capital letter "A" with a small globe at the base of the arch. • To the right of the emblem, the text "ARGUS" appears in large, uppercase serif font, with "RESEARCH" in smaller uppercase letters below it. • The registered trademark symbol (®) appears at the upper right of the "S" in "ARGUS". Technical Details : • The logo uses a white and blue color palette. • The emblem and text are horizontally aligned. • The globe within the arch is detailed with latitude and longitude lines. Spatial Relationships : • The emblem is positioned to the left of the text. • "ARGUS" is the dominant text, with "RESEARCH" centered below it in a smaller font. Analysis : • The use of a globe and archway suggests a global or research-oriented focus, and the clean, professional design conveys credibility and authority. Our rating on the Information Technology sector is Over-Weight. Consumer electronics demand, which was reduced by inflation, is now showing signs of recovery. IT demand in enterprise and data center markets weakened after consumer demand but now also shows signs of recovery, fueled by mounting interest in generative AI. As of the end of May, the sector accounted for 31.6% of the S&P 500. Over the past five years, the weighting has ranged from 16% to 33%. The sector was underperforming the market, with a loss of 1.8%. The sector outperformed in 2024, with a gain of 35.7% compared to a gain of 23.3% for the S&P 500. The sector’s P/E ratio on projected 2026 EPS was 23, above the market multiple. Yields of 0.2% were below the market average. The sector’s smoothed earnings growth rate of 15% was above the market average. Over the long term, we expect the Tech sector to benefit from pervasive digitization across the economy, greater acceptance of transformative technologies, and the development of the Internet of Things (IoT). Generative AI is poised to become a huge industry driver, although timeline of actual AI deployments is uncertain. Healthy company and sector fundamentals are also positive. For individual companies, these include high cash levels, low debt, and broad international business exposure. # Key Sector Trends ## Communications Equipment - • Data demand is exploding because of mobile internet, video on the web, social networking and other factors. Generative AI has shifted from an emerging driver to perhaps the most-significant factor in communications equipment demand. AI is driving demand for bandwidth capacity at the optical transport level as well as network efficiency (IP) and ubiquity (Ethernet) at the access level. - • Prevailing trends in the global information society - including collaboration, virtualization, cloud, social networking, and exponential growth in "big" file-based data - are driving the need for more network "intelligence," meaning security, efficiency, extensibility, personalization, and sophisticated data management. Mobility, once a voice-centric domain, now encompasses mobile internet, and this reality - • is impacting device demand trends in computing and communications. Information Processing - • AI is driving growth in computing, both in GPU-based servers and in on-device Gen AI for PCs and smartphones. It also is disrupting the data center, as cloud service providers accelerate growth with the help of leading computing and semiconductor companies. . - Overall semiconductor demand, formerly driven first by PCs and then by the proliferation of mobile devices, now has multiple secular drivers. These include AI data center, legacy cloud data center, Internet of Things (IoT) & factory automation, EV & hybrid EV, autonomous vehicles, robotics, and more. - The need for massive GPU clusters to train Large Language Models (LLMs) and for inferencing for generative AI has led to explosive demand for GPU computing implementations and has become as one of the most significant semiconductor drivers. - ARM-based cores (licensed from ARM Holdings Ltd.) that power smartphones and tablet PCs have disrupted the hegemony in processing once enjoyed by x86 architecture. Traditional x86 processor companies such as Intel and AMD are fighting back with lower-power products that integrate central processing and graphics processing within a single die. - The nature of memory is changing, with mobile computers transitioning away from hard disk drive-based memory (HDD) to solid-state memory (SSD). Memory demand too is accelerating as data storage accommodates massive AI-related traffic flows. - New software-centric developments such as collaboration, virtualization, cloud computing, SaaS, analytics, and interactivity are transferring the software power center onto public and private cloud networks serving enterprises. At the same time, advances in mobility and competitive developments have driven demand for mobile devices and, in turn, mobile applications supplied by nontraditional players. - These factors have diminished the central role once played by Microsoft's operating system and applications. At the same time, enterprise software companies have prioritized enabling AI for their customers, leading to strong growth for major industry participants including Salesforce Inc, ServiceNow, Oracle, and more. © 2025 Argus Research Company ARGUS A6 Report logo: ARGUS RESEARCH • The image is a logo for "ARGUS RESEARCH". • The logo consists of a blue background with a white circular emblem on the left. Inside the circle is a stylized archway or capital letter "A" with a small globe at the base of the arch. • To the right of the emblem, the word "ARGUS" is written in large, uppercase serif font, with a registered trademark symbol (®) at the upper right of the "S". • Below "ARGUS", the word "RESEARCH" appears in smaller, spaced-out uppercase letters. • The overall dimensions are horizontal, with the emblem on the left and text on the right. Analysis : • The logo uses a blue and white color scheme, which conveys professionalism and trust. • The globe within the arch suggests a global or international focus, while the arch or "A" shape reinforces the company name. • The serif font and clean layout communicate a sense of authority and reliability, appropriate for a research or analytics firm. Argus A6 Quantitative Universe Our A6 Quantitative Universe includes more than 1,500 companies that are diversified across all asset classes and industry sectors. Ratings for these companies are derived through a proprietary algorithm we have designed and tested so that the ratings are based on our fundamental Six-Point System. Our A6 Quantitative Ratings include sub-ratings for each of the six factors. The A6 algorithm is designed to capture and analyze financial trends for each company under coverage. Companies are measured against their historical record, peer group, and the broad market. For each covered company, the A6 algorithm generates a subrating for growth, financial strength, industry outlook, management, risk/safety and valuation. These scores are totaled and provide an overall rating for each company. The A6 algorithm rates stocks on growth based on normalized earnings estimates and sales trends, among other factors. Our financial strength ranking is based primarily on balance sheet debt and liquidity ratios. For risk, we factor in liquidity, dividend yield, market cap, debt leverage and stock price beta. Our valuation subrating includes factors such as price/earnings and price/sales ratios, trend lines, and discounted cash flow valuations. Ratings are reviewed weekly. Argus Research Disclaimer Argus Research Co. (ARC) is an independent investment research provider whose parent company, Argus Investors' Counsel, Inc. (AIC), is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Argus Investors' Counsel is a subsidiary of The Argus Research Group, Inc. Neither The Argus Research Group nor any affiliate is a member of the FINRA or the SIPC. Argus Research is not a registered broker dealer and does not have investment banking operations. The Argus trademark, service mark and logo are the intellectual property of The Argus Research Group, Inc. The information contained in this research report is produced and copyrighted by Argus Research Co., and any unauthorized use, duplication, redistribution or disclosure is prohibited by law and can result in prosecution. The content of this report may be derived from Argus research reports, notes, or analyses. The opinions and information contained herein have been obtained or derived from sources believed to be reliable, but Argus makes no representation as to their timeliness, accuracy or completeness or for their fitness for any particular purpose. In addition, this content is not prepared subject to Canadian disclosure requirements. This report is not an offer to sell or a solicitation of an offer to buy any security. The information and material presented in this report are for general information only and do not specifically address individual investment objectives, financial situations or the particular needs of any specific person who may receive this report. Investing in any security or investment strategies discussed may not be suitable for you and it is recommended that you consult an independent investment advisor. Nothing in this report constitutes individual investment, legal or tax advice. Argus may issue or may have issued other reports that are inconsistent with or may reach different conclusions than those represented in this report, and all opinions are reflective of judgments made on the original date of publication. Argus is under no obligation to ensure that other reports are brought to the attention of any recipient of this report. Argus shall accept no liability for any loss arising from the use of this report, nor shall Argus treat all recipients of this report as customers simply by virtue of their receipt of this material. Investments involve risk and an investor may incur either profits or losses. Past performance should not be taken as an indication or guarantee of future performance. Argus has provided independent research since 1934. Argus officers, employees, agents and/or affiliates have positions in stocks discussed in this report. No Argus officers, employees, agents and/or affiliates may serve as officers or directors of covered companies, or may own more than one percent of a covered company's stock. Argus Investors' Counsel (AIC), a portfolio management business based in Stamford, Connecticut, is a customer of Argus Research Co. (ARC), based in New York. Argus Investors' Counsel pays Argus Research Co. for research used in the management of the AIC core equity strategy and to cover its other customers. However, other than the aforementioned relationship, there is no affiliation between the two companies. Summary : This bar chart displays the distribution of analyst ratings (Buy, Sell, Hold) across different stock market sectors, allowing comparison of sentiment by sector. bar chart: # Title & Axes : • Title: "RATING DISTRIBUTION SECTOR". • X-axis: Number of ratings (no explicit units, tick marks at 0, 50, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300). • Y-axis: Sectors (Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Consumer Staples, Energy, Financial, Healthcare, Industrial, Information Technology, Materials, Real Estate, Utilities). # Data Points : • Sectors listed (top to bottom): Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Consumer Staples, Energy, Financial, Healthcare, Industrial, Information Technology, Materials, Real Estate, Utilities. • For each sector, three horizontal bars represent: – Buy (green) – Sell (red) – Hold (yellow) • Bar lengths (approximate, as exact values are not labeled) show the count of each rating per sector. # Design Encodings : • Buy ratings: green bars. • Sell ratings: red bars. • Hold ratings: yellow bars. • All bars are horizontal and grouped by sector. • Legend at the bottom: green = Buy, red = Sell, yellow = Hold. # Distribution & Trends : • Most sectors have the longest yellow (Hold) bars, indicating Hold is the most common rating. • Sell (red) bars are generally the shortest across all sectors. • Sectors like Financial, Healthcare, and Industrial have notably long Hold bars (approaching or exceeding 250). • Buy (green) bars are present in all sectors but are shorter than Hold bars. • Utilities and Real Estate have the shortest overall bars, indicating fewer total ratings. # Analysis : • Hold is the dominant analyst rating across all sectors, especially in Financial, Healthcare, and Industrial. • Sell ratings are rare in every sector. • Sectors with the most analyst attention (highest total bar lengths) are Financial, Healthcare, and Industrial. • Sectors like Utilities and Real Estate receive fewer ratings overall. • The distribution suggests a generally cautious or neutral analyst sentiment, with few strong Buy or Sell recommendations. Summary : This figure presents the distribution of market capitalisation (market cap) categories—Large Cap, Mid Cap, and Small Cap—across three universes: all stocks, the Argus Fundamental Universe, and the Argus A6 (Quant) Universe, using pie charts. pie charts: # Title & Categories : • Main title: "MARKET CAP DISTRIBUTION". • Three subgroups: "ALL STOCKS", "ARGUS FUNDAMENTAL UNIVERSE", "ARGUS A6 (QUANT) UNIVERSE". • Legend: Large Cap (purple), Mid Cap (yellow), Small Cap (green). # Data Points : • ALL STOCKS: – Large Cap: 45.8% – Mid Cap: 34.3% – Small Cap: 19.8% • ARGUS FUNDAMENTAL UNIVERSE: – Large Cap: 86.4% – Mid Cap: 10.5% – Small Cap: 3% • ARGUS A6 (QUANT) UNIVERSE: – Large Cap: 44.9% – Mid Cap: 27.8% – Small Cap: 27.3% # Design Encodings : • Pie charts with three segments each, colour-coded: purple (Large Cap), yellow (Mid Cap), green (Small Cap). • Percentages labelled directly on each segment. • Legend box clarifies colour-to-category mapping. # Distribution & Trends : • ALL STOCKS: Distribution is spread across all three categories, with Large Cap being the largest segment. • ARGUS FUNDAMENTAL UNIVERSE: Dominated by Large Cap stocks (over 86%), with very small Small Cap representation. • ARGUS A6 (QUANT) UNIVERSE: More balanced, with Large Cap and Small Cap both near 45% and 27%, respectively. # Analysis : • The Argus Fundamental Universe is heavily skewed toward Large Cap stocks, with minimal Small Cap presence. • The Argus A6 (Quant) Universe has a more even distribution between Large, Mid, and Small Cap stocks, closely mirroring the overall "All Stocks" distribution but with a slightly higher Small Cap proportion. • The "All Stocks" group shows a moderate spread, with Large Cap as the largest single category but not overwhelmingly dominant. Summary : This bar chart shows the current distribution of analyst ratings categorized as Buy, Sell, and Hold, with corresponding percentages and approximate counts. bar chart: Title & Axes : • Title: "CURRENT RATING DISTRIBUTION". • X-axis: Rating categories ("Buy", "Sell", "Hold"). • Y-axis: Count (range: 0 to 1000, tick marks at 0, 200, 400, 600, 800, 1000). Data Points : • Buy: ~420 (26%). • Sell: ~120 (12%). • Hold: 1000 (62%). Design Encodings : • Buy: Dark green bar, labeled "26%". • Sell: Red bar, labeled "12%". • Hold: Orange bar, labeled "62%". • Bars are vertical, with percentage labels centered at the top of each bar. Distribution & Trends : • Hold ratings are the most frequent, comprising the majority (62%) of the total. • Buy ratings are the second most common (26%). • Sell ratings are the least common (12%). Analysis : • The distribution is heavily skewed toward Hold recommendations, with nearly two-thirds of ratings in this category. • Buy ratings are more than double the Sell ratings, but both are much less frequent than Hold. • The data suggests a strong analyst preference for neutral (Hold) recommendations over definitive Buy or Sell stances. covered company's stock. Argus Investors' Counsel (AIC), a portfolio management business based in Stamford, Connecticut, is a customer of Argus Research Co. (ARC), based in New York. Argus Investors' Counsel pays Argus Research Co. for research used in the management of the AIC core equity strategy and model portfolio and UIT products, and has the same access to Argus Research Co. reports as other customers. However, clients and prospective clients should note that Argus Investors' Counsel and Argus Research Co., as units of The Argus Research Group, have certain employees in common, including those with both research and portfolio management responsibilities, and that Argus Research Co. employees participate in the management and marketing of the AIC core equity strategy and UIT and model portfolio products. © 2025 Argus Research Company ARGUS A6 Report

  • The logo consists of a blue rectangular background.
  • On the left, there is a white circle containing a stylized archway or column with a small globe at the base.
  • To the right of the icon, the text "ARGUS" appears in large, uppercase serif font, with a registered trademark symbol (®) at the upper right.
  • Below "ARGUS," the word "RESEARCH" is written in smaller, spaced-out uppercase letters.

  • The text is horizontally aligned and centered vertically with the icon.

  • The globe and column/arch motif suggests global reach and stability.

  • Despite fluctuations, the overall trajectory is positive, with the final value being the highest in the series.

Over the past year, NVDA shares are up 18.6%, versus a gain of 10.5% for the broader market. The 52 week trading range is $86.62 to $160.98. The Argus A6 target price is $208 representing a 30% gain from the current level.
Nvidia is a leading developer of graphics processing units. Traditionally, GPUs were used to enhance the experience on computing platforms, most notably in gaming applications on PCs.

Our rating on the Information Technology sector is Over-Weight. Consumer electronics demand, which was reduced by inflation, is now showing signs of recovery. IT demand in enterprise and data center markets weakened after consumer demand but now also shows signs of recovery, fueled by mounting interest in generative AI.

As of the end of May, the sector accounted for 31.6% of the S&P 500. Over the past
five years, the weighting has ranged from 16% to 33%. The sector was
underperforming the market, with a loss of 1.8%. The sector outperformed in 2024,
with a gain of 35.7% compared to a gain of 23.3% for the S&P 500.

The sector’s P/E ratio on projected 2026 EPS was 23, above the market multiple. Yields of 0.2% were below the market average. The sector’s smoothed earnings growth rate of 15% was above the market average.

Over the long term, we expect the Tech sector to benefit from pervasive digitization across the economy, greater acceptance of transformative technologies, and the development of the Internet of Things (IoT). Generative AI is poised to become a huge industry driver, although timeline of actual AI deployments is uncertain. Healthy company and sector fundamentals are also positive. For individual companies, these include high cash levels, low debt, and broad international business exposure.

# Key Sector Trends

## Communications Equipment

- • Data demand is exploding because of mobile internet, video on the web, social networking and other factors. Generative AI has shifted from an emerging driver to perhaps the most-significant factor in communications equipment demand. AI is driving demand for bandwidth capacity at the optical transport level as well as network efficiency (IP) and ubiquity (Ethernet) at the access level.
- • Prevailing trends in the global information society - including collaboration, virtualization, cloud, social networking, and exponential growth in "big" file-based data - are driving the need for more network "intelligence," meaning security, efficiency, extensibility, personalization, and sophisticated data management. Mobility, once a voice-centric domain, now encompasses mobile internet, and this reality

- • is impacting device demand trends in computing and communications.

Information Processing

- • AI is driving growth in computing, both in GPU-based servers and in on-device Gen AI for PCs and smartphones. It also is disrupting the data center, as cloud service providers accelerate growth with the help of leading computing and semiconductor companies. .

- Overall semiconductor demand, formerly driven first by PCs and then by the proliferation of mobile devices, now has multiple secular drivers. These include AI data center, legacy cloud data center, Internet of Things (IoT) & factory automation, EV & hybrid EV, autonomous vehicles, robotics, and more.
- The need for massive GPU clusters to train Large Language Models (LLMs) and for inferencing for generative AI has led to explosive demand for GPU computing implementations and has become as one of the most significant semiconductor drivers.
- ARM-based cores (licensed from ARM Holdings Ltd.) that power smartphones and tablet PCs have disrupted the hegemony in processing once enjoyed by x86 architecture. Traditional x86 processor companies such as Intel and AMD are fighting back with lower-power products that integrate central processing and graphics processing within a single die.
- The nature of memory is changing, with mobile computers transitioning away from hard disk drive-based memory (HDD) to solid-state memory (SSD). Memory demand too is accelerating as data storage accommodates massive AI-related traffic flows.

- New software-centric developments such as collaboration, virtualization, cloud computing, SaaS, analytics, and interactivity are transferring the software power center onto public and private cloud networks serving enterprises. At the same time, advances in mobility and competitive developments have driven demand for mobile devices and, in turn, mobile applications supplied by nontraditional players.
- These factors have diminished the central role once played by Microsoft's operating system and applications. At the same time, enterprise software companies have prioritized enabling AI for their customers, leading to strong growth for major industry participants including Salesforce Inc, ServiceNow, Oracle, and more.

Argus A6 Quantitative Universe

Our A6 Quantitative Universe includes more than 1,500 companies that are diversified across all asset classes and industry sectors. Ratings for these companies are derived through a proprietary algorithm we have designed and tested so that the ratings are based on our fundamental Six-Point System. Our A6 Quantitative Ratings include sub-ratings for each of the six factors.

The A6 algorithm is designed to capture and analyze financial trends for each company under coverage. Companies are measured against their historical record, peer group, and the broad market. For each covered company, the A6 algorithm generates a subrating for growth, financial strength, industry outlook, management, risk/safety and valuation. These scores are totaled and provide an overall rating for each company. The A6 algorithm rates stocks on growth based on normalized earnings estimates and sales trends, among other factors. Our financial strength ranking is based primarily on balance sheet debt and liquidity ratios. For risk, we factor in liquidity, dividend yield, market cap, debt leverage and stock price beta. Our valuation subrating includes factors such as price/earnings and price/sales ratios, trend lines, and discounted cash flow valuations. Ratings are reviewed weekly.

Summary : This bar chart displays the distribution of analyst ratings (Buy, Sell, Hold) across different stock market sectors, allowing comparison of sentiment by sector.

bar chart:
# Title & Axes :
  • Title: "RATING DISTRIBUTION SECTOR".
  • X-axis: Number of ratings (no explicit units, tick marks at 0, 50, 100, 150, 200, 250, 300).
  • Y-axis: Sectors (Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Consumer Staples, Energy, Financial, Healthcare, Industrial, Information Technology, Materials, Real Estate, Utilities).

# Data Points :
  • Sectors listed (top to bottom): Communication Services, Consumer Discretionary, Consumer Staples, Energy, Financial, Healthcare, Industrial, Information Technology, Materials, Real Estate, Utilities.
  • For each sector, three horizontal bars represent:
    – Buy (green)
    – Sell (red)
    – Hold (yellow)
  • Bar lengths (approximate, as exact values are not labeled) show the count of each rating per sector.

# Design Encodings :
  • Buy ratings: green bars.
  • Sell ratings: red bars.
  • Hold ratings: yellow bars.
  • All bars are horizontal and grouped by sector.
  • Legend at the bottom: green = Buy, red = Sell, yellow = Hold.

# Distribution & Trends :
  • Most sectors have the longest yellow (Hold) bars, indicating Hold is the most common rating.
  • Sell (red) bars are generally the shortest across all sectors.
  • Sectors like Financial, Healthcare, and Industrial have notably long Hold bars (approaching or exceeding 250).
  • Buy (green) bars are present in all sectors but are shorter than Hold bars.
  • Utilities and Real Estate have the shortest overall bars, indicating fewer total ratings.

# Analysis :
  • Hold is the dominant analyst rating across all sectors, especially in Financial, Healthcare, and Industrial.
  • Sell ratings are rare in every sector.
  • Sectors with the most analyst attention (highest total bar lengths) are Financial, Healthcare, and Industrial.
  • Sectors like Utilities and Real Estate receive fewer ratings overall.
  • The distribution suggests a generally cautious or neutral analyst sentiment, with few strong Buy or Sell recommendations.

Summary : This bar chart shows the current distribution of analyst ratings categorized as Buy, Sell, and Hold, with corresponding percentages and approximate counts.

bar chart:
Title & Axes :
  • Title: "CURRENT RATING DISTRIBUTION".
  • X-axis: Rating categories ("Buy", "Sell", "Hold").
  • Y-axis: Count (range: 0 to 1000, tick marks at 0, 200, 400, 600, 800, 1000).

Data Points :
  • Buy: ~420 (26%).
  • Sell: ~120 (12%).
  • Hold: 1000 (62%).

Design Encodings :
  • Buy: Dark green bar, labeled "26%".
  • Sell: Red bar, labeled "12%".
  • Hold: Orange bar, labeled "62%".
  • Bars are vertical, with percentage labels centered at the top of each bar.

Distribution & Trends :
  • Hold ratings are the most frequent, comprising the majority (62%) of the total.
  • Buy ratings are the second most common (26%).
  • Sell ratings are the least common (12%).

Analysis :
  • The distribution is heavily skewed toward Hold recommendations, with nearly two-thirds of ratings in this category.
  • Buy ratings are more than double the Sell ratings, but both are much less frequent than Hold.
  • The data suggests a strong analyst preference for neutral (Hold) recommendations over definitive Buy or Sell stances.
